xyz.acygn.mokapot

Interface LongReference

  • All Known Subinterfaces:
    Standin<T>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    IndirectStandin

    public interface LongReference
    Common interface for all long references. Note that this contains no methods of its own (otherwise they could have naming clashes with methods of the object being referenced). See DistributionUtils for methods that interact with long references.

    A "long reference" is similar to a Java reference; however, the referent is not necessarily on the same machine. Invoking methods on the long reference will invoke those methods on the object itself, including potentially across a network. As such, the long reference acts as an exact equivalent of the object itself.

    Additionally, if a long reference is cloned, it still points to the same object. A long reference cannot be sent over a network directly, but it can be sent indirectly via marshalling it on the source system, and unmarshalling it on the destination system; doing this will create a new long reference that points to the same object as the original. However, explicitly marshalling and unmarshalling long references, rather than allowing this to happen automatically as part of a distributed communication, requires care as it denies information to the garbage collector, which will not be able to know whether the serialisation of the reference is stored anywhere. In such a case, the copy of the marshalled reference (that was received from the network) can be unmarshalled only while the original marshalled reference (that was sent over the network) is held alive (although if it is unmarshalled correctly, it will then act like a normal strong reference to the object).

    This class is mostly public for technical reasons (it allows long references to be created in any package without violating Java's rules about which packages a class can exist in); it's not intended to be used directly by a user. In particular, "methods on LongReference" (actually static methods of DistributionUtils) work via scanning all known long reference implementations to see if they generated the long reference, and then using knowledge of their implementation details to access the internals of the long reference; as such, implementing this interface yourself is a bad idea.

    Author:
    Alex Smith
    See Also:
    DistributionUtils
